pros: Good partners in research environment, people are friendly.
cons: Space is difficult to acquire on campus for research teams.

review_title: You Will Never Get a Raise.
pros: ample time off & health insurance coverage
cons: The salaries are abysmal and there is no upward mobility. You will never get a raise, and they will give you the run around on every request you make for one. They act like it is a blessing you’re even employed there at all. I’ve also never seen an institution so obsessed with self-preservation. The employees come dead last in their list of priorities, and they will steamroll you if they have to. HR is either absent or downright mean and vindictive. Just don’t work here. Everyone leaves for better pay and opportunities, and instead of reflecting on why that might be, they just keep hiring new people and doing the same thing.

pros: Good pay flexible NETWORKING lot of opportunity
cons: Large company, poor work flow, micromanagement, low morale

pros: strong research community and resources.
cons: Academia pay level is terrible compared with equivalent industry experience. However, that's true at all academic institutions.

pros: Very good work environment and work life balance

pros: Not much to say about the administrative side of TJU. Some faculty members act humanely toward their workers (Ph.D. students and postdocs), not pushing them to work to death. Others don't have that sensibility.
cons: TJU does not pay living wages to most of its manual laborers. That includes highly educated research workers. They only pay 33K/year to Ph.D. students without dental and vision insurance. Their postdoc wages start close to NIH postdoc stipends, but the annual increases do not follow the NIH rates, and the benefits package is dreary.

pros: Work life balance is good Good work culture PTO & Maternal/Paternal Leave

review_title: Has Potential but Don't Waste Your Time
pros: Flexibility Good work-life balance Health benefits Tuition Assistance if you plan to further your education Center City and easy commute
cons: Poor pay No upward mobility unless you get more degrees Poor management/leadership (broken promises, no accountability, no leadership, no transparency, severely understaffed) Siloed departments and offices No professional development opportunities Does not care about your career and growth (does not follow through with annual reviews and goals) Poor employee onboarding (lack of support) Employees are leaving constantly for better opportunities, and Jefferson cannot retain employees HR is a nightmare to deal with, slow, understaffed, and incompetent

review_title: Small college eaten by massive enterprise breeds predictable results
job_title: Office Administrator in East Falls, PA
pros: Staff, for the most part, really care about their work and the students. It's a beautiful campus, and I imagine if you found the right office to settle into, without an expectation of "going the extra mile" aka working outside of 9-5 MF for your meager salary that barely surpasses minimum wage after taxes.......you might be able to stay here for quite a while.
cons: Unfortunately, trying to merge small arts college culture with massive medical university culture doesn't work. There's two people for every one position, an East Falls person and a Center City person. Frequently, they are at odds with one another for no good reason. People are stubborn on principle. It's almost impossible to get either side to accept that these two worlds have merged and that both sides need to compromise, so oftentimes there are two different processes for things...which is frustrating for faculty, staff and students. Everyone is underpaid, which is common in higher ed, but as part of an enterprise that can afford to keep purchasing new hospitals, it chafes. It's next to impossible to get a raise, a promotion, or to change the job description of an existing role. Staff generally seem overworked, resentful, mistrustful, and territorial...not a good environment for experimenting with new ways of doing things. I don't blame the staff, I blame the culture. Management takes advantage of how much people genuinely care about their work, the students, and their coworkers. Workers should unionize but.....that doesn't seem likely.

pros: I've been employed at Jefferson for 20 years, and I echo a lot of what other employees are saying.  I would have to say that the people here (for the most part) make the top of the list.  I have a great network of individuals that I know I can turn to for help and support.
cons: No real room for advancement.  Their employee development programs consist of 2-3 day workshops rather than more sincere involvement, such as coaching and mentoring (this is reserved for those already in leadership positions).  Also, the pay scale is below the average, and we have to work with incredibly tight budgets. The other con is the political and bureaucratic environment.   It's really difficult to make any real progress.  And lastly, the technology needs to be upgraded.  They use outdated browsers and none of the systems talk to each other.

review_title: This is no way to run a company
pros: If you are lazy you get the same rewards as hard workers and plan to retire here if you have no ambition.  Decent benefits and time off if you don't call out; plenty of time to schedule.
cons: 2% increase if you are lucky.  This place is a BOY's club.  If you belong you are a VP if not forget about a promotion or any meaningful money.  Decisions are based on what the folks at the top want, not what makes sense for the company.  Departments do what they want, no consistency--HR directives are ignored in some departments while others hold your feet to the fire.  If you are salaried and have a brain they will stress you out.

review_title: depends on the department you work in
pros: I've has some excellent experiences with one department I worked in.
cons: The worst has got to be the practice of hiding salaries. Most universities have a "grade system: your job is a 20, 25, 60 or whatever. However at Jefferson people doing the same job in various departments can be entirely different grades. Also there's no chart where you can go and check, for instance to see the salary range of a "J-60" so you never know what you can really be paid. Last, most job announcement do not even tell the grade so you are left wondering if the job is a promotion or demotion or just lateral move.

pros: Thomas Jefferson University is a great place to work because of the following: its well-renowned faculty, cutting-edge healthcare education, hardworking & motivated students.  Colleagues are very professional, are open to collaboration and are dedicated to excellence.  Jefferson offers great healthcare and tuition benefits.  There are many professional development opportunities offered to employees, to enrich and broaden their skills in a variety of areas.  The university is growing in terms of student body size, academic programs offered, and in campus construction and development.  The campus is in a central location in downtown Philadelphia, making it a safe, vibrant place to work.  It is an exciting time to be a part of Jefferson.
cons: There are no major complaints.  Overall, they do a pretty good job of treating their employees well.

review_title: It was a good ride part of the way
pros: A lot of fantastic and caring colleagues, especially among clinicians and staff.  Fantastic medical school.  Great NCI-designated cancer center.
cons: Deep problems at leadership level for the past decade (and possibly before) with power silos at constant war. New President is inspirational but will have his hands full with ingrained leadership dysfunctions that hamper real progress. Top-down salary-reduction plan based on retroactive performance metrics is demoralizing and will hinder recruitment and retention of faculty.

pros: Name recognition of working at a major healthcare provider in the area, good healthcare
cons: In my time there, it was clear that there was a culture that senior faculty could act anyway within the university and face little to no consequences. Several professor were accused of sexual and verbal harassment and while a show investigation took place, the professors received a slap on the wrist and continued normal duties as long as they continued bringing money into the school. The mistreatment of employees was well known among the staff and among management at the university but nothing was done. Your ability to move upward was also determined by the same people abusing the staff so many people got stuck in the same positions for years with no raises or promotions.

pros: Great looking nursing and medical students. Most employees are down to earth and there are good friendships to be had. Jefferson is located in one of the nicest parts of center city. There are lots of places to eat for lunch and whatever your need is there is a place close by to satisfy it. It is close to all forms of public transportation and is a heartbeat away from Independence hall and the rest of the most historical places in the country. Old City is only a 10 minute walk from jefferson's campus and is a great place to spend happy hour.
cons: Management is awful. People are treated very unfairly. Jefferson management has a very elitist attitude. Management definately does not believe that a happy employee is a productive employee. The company itself is poorly run and politics dictates almost anything that happens.

review_title: Great people and great learning experience
job_title: Clinical Research Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Lots of exposure to healthcare professionals.  Great place to learn and gain relevant health care experience. Small department sizes means you are constantly busy and taking on new responsibilities.  People are wonderful and very helpful.  Easily accessible through public transportation.  Good benefits.
cons: The department I work in is a bit of a mess at the moment.  Many people have looked for new opportunities outside Jefferson because of management issues.

pros: Front Line staff and middle management committed to doing what is best for the student and the patient -- even without adequate resources. Great institutional reputation.
cons: Frenetic approach to change, lack of understanding from leadership of day to day operations and what it takes to keep the lights on while they acquire their next organization, middle management consistently squeezed to do more and operate a level or two below their hired positions, very little time to manage or develop staff, work-life balance lacking, leadership fragmented with different agendas

review_title: Okay place to get my foot in the door- not a place to stay long term
pros: This is an okay position to start as a recent grad.  There are also a lot of networking opportunities if you want to move around within Jefferson.  However, without a higher degree or certification, getting the right pay is really tough to find.  Awesome benefits and insurance.
cons: As a tech at TJU, there's zero room to grow- you are low on the totem pole, and have also reached the glass ceiling.  With the high turnover rate, there are always positions like this open.  But when a better opportunity comes along, TAKE IT!

job_title: Patient Registrar II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The benefits package that Jefferson offers is AMAZING!
cons: Seniority trumps everything and everyone at this office. If you are new and you have any issues with a "senior" worker, you are automatically wrong! You cannot confide in management. It's more of a high school than workplace. If you don't get in with the "popular crowd then you can just kiss your job goodbye.

review_title: Research Assistant in Thomas Jefferson University
pros:
Great Benefits
 Good Work -Life balance
Flexible working hours
cons:
No growth
very low pay structure
no encouragement for internal career transfers

review_title: Great place to work once you get set in the system
pros: Cutting edge of biomedical and clinical research, visionary top management, lot of great colleagues, highly reputed institution, opportunities to work on key clinical problems
cons: Burdensome administrative procedures, things move slowly and hence takes too much time to effect big changes, information technology services is not up to the latest capabilities, conventional mentality in evaluation for promotions

job_title: Ph D Candidate in Philadelphia, PA
pros: This is a great PhD Program with very competent professors.  As with any PhD program you should be self motivated and expect a lot of work.  They don't give out degrees for free; stop whining and do your work.  The reward is a great degree.
cons: Executives put more money into the exterior appearance of the buildings than the function on the inside; e.g. new signs and old elevators.  But hey, take the stairs.

review_title: Started with promise, ended in dispair
pros: Started with great benefits, lots of vacation, fairly willing to teach you if you're willing to learn.
cons: Management is absolutely clueless as to productivity of people.  Very little telecommuting, even for IT staff with no need to be there.  FREQUENT overtime with an oncall routine that usually leaves one destroyed.  One raise in 4 years despite never once receiving anything less than "Exceeds Expectations" on reviews.  Political drama made moving to government seem tame in comparison.  Almost no room for advancement.

review_title: Great if you're a PhD and a man, otherwise, get what you need and get out.
pros: Interesting work, possibly some expertise, some freedom in work, good meetings/talks.
cons: Inflexible schedule, deathmarch style hours in the lab, if you don't have PhD you are worthless, very little vision; mostly short term thinking, male dominated to an extreme amount, terrible management of funds and people.

pros: The community there at Thomas Jefferson is very welcoming and easy to get used to. They University is beginning to expand and there is room for growth when you start at an entry level position.
cons: Some departments are still just beginning to expand what they need to function the way they need to. The facilities were tight while I was there, but they are improving them as well giving departments that are growing more space to work.

pros: The pros are the people.  Yes, there are some crazies as anywhere else, but the good ones are some of the nicest I've ever worked with.  If you don't have a degree yet, the tuition benefits are fantastic!  The medical benefits and paid time off are also hard to beat.
cons: Anyone I've known who has left Jefferson is making more money doing the same job somewhere else.  The Boy's Club is also rampant here with white men over 55 running the show.

pros: They have a good benefits package
cons:
Most upper mgmt there a very long time (+25 years) and out of touch with the world
General Tech level is very poor
People who know how to get things done are leaned on for everything
Poor communication
No rewards/respect for technical excellence

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Friendly people are found in most departments, except some nurses. Research being performed is interesting to partake in. Very flexible scheduling.
cons: Not a lot of room for career growth in research unless you switch between departments. Floor nurses are lazy and don't want to assist with research activities, even though it is their attending running the research and part of their job description. Nurses have a condescending attitude to anyone who is not a nurse.

review_title: Top down approach, doesn't work well.
pros: There are some decent faculty members for research, however current policy changes are  quickly driving away faculty.
cons: Poor management. Top down approach, with little consideration of how policies affect individuals. Science facilities are in a mediocre condition.

review_title: Lead Psychometrist testing patients, training team members and clinical/research database management
job_title: Team Lead/Neuropsychology Technician in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Psychometrics, analytical work, great team environment, great supervisors, learn a lot about neuropsychology, and neural/psychopathology. Great clinical patient interaction experience for those looking to pursue medical career.
cons: Testing patients can be exhausting. Can be very fast paced, but good for skill development. Very much a transition job for undergraduates and graduates. Hard to grow within department.

pros:
Benefits are probably the only positive. Pretty reasonable cost but the co pays are great if you use Jefferson doctors.
Days off are pretty good
cons: Pay is poor but it's a union contract. Lots of management who have no clue as to how to run a proper public safety security department. Technology is very poor from a security stand point.

review_title: Company is a great honor to work for
job_title: Clinical Research Nurse I in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great benefits such as health insurance, 401K after 1 year, tuition reimbursement, Bring your child to work day, the new CEO has so many visions to bring about great change and I can already see positive changes across the campus
cons: Low salary, not enough staff, each individual department have their own dramas, people are constantly "telling on each other"

pros: Stable work place, do your job, fit in, disappear (can be a con). Many people there for a long time in the same jobs.
cons: You have to be upper management for any chance to grow.  Many people in supervisory positions have no management training; you need to be self guiding; forget about any real training, you learn as you go.

review_title: Be careful which department you're in...
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Easy access to a wide range of health care professionals if needed. Decent benefits. Easily accessible with public transportation. Discounted train passes.
cons: Depends on the department you're in. I heard wonderful things about other depts but the one I worked for had a very toxic work environment. Pay seemed to be on the low side.

pros: The greatest pro is being on a university/hospital campus surrounded by the various team members that contribute to the flow of the company. As a research assistant, this is a great place to work.
cons: There seems to be a lot of "politics." Jefferson is no exception, MDs are difficult people to work under. Also, I question the money-related research procedures.

pros: Locate in the downtown of Philadelphia.  Very close to chinatown. Close and convenient to buy almost every thing.  But the benefit is quite good. .
cons: not so good experience. too many political s, small and not safe. Not like a university.  Dirty and lots of burger around.

pros: I love my job and the immediate people I work with. I have good bosses and good colleagues directly at the level of my job and management in my department.
cons: I get the impression that higher level management and administration are setting out deliberately to create a work force that's angry and resentful. Specifics: I'm a part-time employee so I'm not on the work site every day. To access my income and tax records, I have to make a special trip to the work site to use their on-site computers because the program won't work on a remote computer. I'm blocked. Once when I visited the HR office in person to get help for the problem, the woman standing right in front of me and talking to me would do nothing for me. She told me the only help I could get was on the HR web site. Another debacle is their public transport discount, about 10 percent off for one of the monthly passes offered by area public transit. They send the passes out in the U.S. mail, which is unreliable. If your pass (which can be expensive) is lost in the mail, they won't issue you another one. You're left paying double for a month's travel, penalized for participating in a program that's meant to save us money. This has happened to me. As a part-time employee on a tight budget, neither the challenge of finding my income and tax info nor double the cost of transportation is affordable for me. There's a general attitude of wanting to make life as difficult as possible for us as employees. Maybe it's different at higher levels. But if I have to deal with any department other than the one where I work, it usually isn't a good experience.

pros: Great outlook for the hospital, being the eternal second biggest in Philadelphia creates ample goals without a lot of stress, leadership communicates pretty well, company actually cares about things like LEAN thinking.
cons: Company is growing too fast, no top-down leadership to facilitate connecting all of the new Jeffersons, below average pay, the amount of projects outpaces the available staff to complete them.

review_title: Good place to learn, but with considerable space for improvement.
job_title: Post Doctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: An exciting clinical environment, a lot to learn and to do.
cons: Low salary, less than perfect organization. Some postdocs are treated like animal feeders, the supervisor make them stay in the lab for 15 hours. There is also other people that are rude and arrogant. Yet they are precious to the bosses for their loyalty.

pros: Organization as a whole is growing. They are actively recruiting new faculty and expanding their research capabilities.
cons: If you are looking to get teaching experience during graduate school, there is no undergraduate population so you have to seek it out on your own.

review_title: Excellent health service provider and medical school
job_title: Clinical Research Engineer and Visiting Faculty in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The health care standards and medical professionals are excellent. Most employees are very driven and with strong work ethic.
cons: Although research is on paper highly thought of, the reality is that it is considered a hobby for otherwise too busy clinicians. Most full-time research personnel are not really happy with their role and position at Thomas Jefferson University.

review_title: Jefferson is a good place to work
pros:
The People that work there are excellent
The ability to help others in a time of need
There are opportunities at many locations because of expansion
cons:
Many decisions of the decision makers do not practice what they preach
A culture of managers sitting in offices

pros:
- Prestigious university
- Kimmel Cancer Center (KCC) is National Cancer Institute- designated
cons:
- Funding is running out fast and because of that upper management has put too much stress on employees
- You can feel the stress, tension, and fear in the lab environments

job_title: Research Assistant C in Magnolia, NJ
pros: I've learned a lot working in a research lab here. My PI is very flexible. I get a good amount of vacation/paid days off
cons: While the job I do is rewarding and makes me feel like I'm making a difference, the salary is definitely not enough for me to make a living, especially since I've received my Master's degree.

pros: Time passes quickly. Great location. Coworkers on night shift were awesome. Teamwork is essential. The patients appreciated our service. Over time was available at times.
cons: Management was great. They just needed to communicate better with the nursing staff. We had downfalls where directors would fudge expected outcomes in lieu of what management knew as possible.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: good benefits, supportive boss, not too much micromanaging
cons: no work/life balance options (work from home, flexible scheduling, etc), low salary

pros: Some excellent faculty; productive contacts between research faculty and clinical faculty
cons: Low pay; attacking tenure commitments; no funds for modern instruments; excess funds for management, big signs, and advertising; focus only on hospital; provost often out of town to develop his personal companies

pros:
Most analysts and technical people are good at their jobs and easy to work with.

Great health benefits
cons:
IS&T (specifically Epic) leadership are toxic and aggressive. There is a culture of finger pointing and blame.

Very high turnover.

review_title: Worth trying once, don't stay as long as I did thinking anything will actually change
pros: Location, ease of access via public transportation, breadth of technologies used/exposed to
cons: Stale salaries, difficult to advance, everything is politics

pros: Great benefits, job security, I'm sure some departments are great
cons: No room for growth within the organization, terrible pay, doesn't value employees at all, treats everyone like they could be replaced tomorrow

pros: Highly respected university and hospital, high growth due to mergers and acquisitions , great managers, empathetic human resource department. There is a lot of teamwork in the hospital, everyone doing their personal best.
cons: Consolidation of jobs due to mergers, recent mass lay offs.

pros: Great benefits competitive salary diverse staff, generous time off , very professional culture , company strives for excellence and helps their employees to active it.
cons:
Work hours can be long when working on projects including weekends and holidays.
Organization chart can be quite unclear at time and changes frequently

pros: Very laid back/good work environment. Staff is friendly and supportive. Patient population comes from South Philly neighborhood. Mostly friendly patient population.
cons: Low pay compared to what other surrounding hospitals would offer. The hospital is old and needs more repairs/upkeep which the patients sometimes complain about.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: health insurance they provide is good.
cons: first they made me to use my sick days and vacation days during my maternity leave. then that they paid std for a short period of time. after that I wasn't paid at all. I don't feel appreciated or valued.

review_title: I've been at Jefferson over a decade
pros: Job security! Jefferson also gives great benefits, such as contributing to a retirement fund for their employees.
cons: Not greatest pay, limited recognition and goal setting, slow advancement.

pros: Jefferson is a massive company with great benefits. Most of the people want to be here, coworkers are pleasant. Easy to come in, do your work, and go home, good work/life balance.
cons: training is scarce, it is a learn as you go job.

pros:
great friendships made
Good incentives for some employess
cons:
low pay for senior medical assistant
No room for growth with the title of medical assistant 
lack of respect from mangement

pros: Their training program is completely immersive and prepares you adequately for the position.  Plus, you’re paid.
cons: I have yet to find one.  Apparently other places pay better?  But that claim is unfounded.

pros: Exposure to various technology, innovation and smart people.
cons: A lot of politics to get things accomplished and the pay for most people is on the low side.

review_title: Overall great environment to work in.
job_title: Pct in Township of Washington, NJ
pros: Very friendly staff, the hospital is undergoing many changes but I think for the better. They are expanding the Washington twp campus, should be ready by mid next year.
cons: Sometimes the workload is heavy on some days.

pros: The people who work here are amazing and it is very close to home with good benefits and opportunities to grow my career.
cons: Since it is in the city, it is not the cleanest or safest environment to work in.

pros: My coworkers are great!  We work very well together.
cons:
Little Diversity
The same people get the promotions
In my department, there are no women of color in a position of power, even though they are the ones with the higher level degrees

pros: This job has enabled me to grow and and improve my skills in a field that I love.  These new challenges have made me a better professional.
cons: Keep up the great work

pros: Decent benefits, and some people are friendly and helpful.
cons: Poorly organized management is overloaded and involved in too much to pay attention to what the general staff want/need.

pros: Great company culture. People are extremely helpful and nice. Competent staff on all levels.

review_title: Graduate School is not an easy place
pros: Flexible hours, independent work, many people to approach if you have a problem.
cons: Academia is a cut throat place. Hard work is not necessarily rewarded, but laziness gets you ignored.

review_title: Work Study as a Student at Jefferson
job_title: Work Study Student in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The work-study program is very flexible with scheduling around classes; it's a great way to get a little bit more financial aid
cons: You only make minimum wage

pros: My department has the best team of Physicians. I could not ask for a better place to work.
cons: I have no issues I wish pay was a little more a hour

job_title: Circulation Desk Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: you can work on your own submissions when patrons are not approaching the desk
cons: my shift is from 11.30 pm to 2 am. international students don't get other shifts.

review_title: Not the best but not the worst
pros: Friendly work environment... respectful co-workers & management... low cost of health benefits
cons: Not on par with other universities with paid time off... lower salaries than other universities

pros: Great place to work, benefits are not bad.  Everyone gets along, and its pleasant to come to work everyday
cons: Room for advancement, and pay.

pros: So much to learn which can propel you for a better career in research.
cons: Can be overwhelming if you are doing pre and post award for several departments.

pros: Salary varies, depending on the department. Very good benefits. There is no senior management in this position.
cons: Autonomous position, which requires to generate 80% of salary through extramural grant funding.

review_title: Wills eye emergency room at Jefferson

review_title: Jefferson A Great Place to Work
pros: Great benefits, great people, prestigious institution with great reputation in area

review_title: An excellent place to begin your scientific career
pros: freedom to follow the research as you see fit

pros: Great benefits and flexible hours. Pay was not that great.
